name: Famous Pioneers and Their Journeys Quiz / Test | People | 10 Questions

questions.text: Charles Lindbergh made one of the most famous trips of all time: across the Atlantic by air. Where did he land?
questions.explanation:
Paris.

	"Lucky Lindy" was an instant hero, but his luck went sour. His son was kidnapped. His star tarnished later when he was somewhat "friendly" to Nazi Germany.

questions.text: Amelia Earhart's airplane trip is famous for its failure, not for its success. Who accompanied her on her ill-fated final trip?
questions.explanation:
Navigator.

	A dangerous trip: historians now say that it was doomed from the start for a variety of reasons. Amelia took off with navigator Fred Noonan. What happened? No one knows for sure.

questions.text: Lewis and Clark helped pioneer the opening of the American West by exploring the land obtained by Jefferson in the Louisiana Paurchase. The trip was a success, but the aftermath was difficult in some ways. Which statement is true?
options: Lewis and Clark both died mysteriously
Neither Lewis nor Clark died mysteriously
questions.explanation:
Lewis died mysteriously.

	Clark lived out his life in a normal manner, but Lewis died under curious circumstances. It is unclear to this day as to whether it was suicide - Lewis was said to be depressed - or murder. It was not, however, "natural causes".

questions.text: Another key to the opening of the American West was the Chisholm Trail. Which of these towns was the northern terminus of the trail from 1867 to 1871 and a major cattle market?
questions.explanation:
Abilene.

	Great stuff for any number of Western movies.

questions.text: The "trail of tears" was a legendary "walk" by what Indian tribe?
questions.explanation:
Cherokee.

	Not the finest moment in American History. There's a reason for the descriptive name.

questions.text: Xenophon led a famous retreat in ancient times after his commanding  generals had been killed in combat. What troops did Xenophon lead home?
questions.explanation:
Greek.

	Xenophon led the Greeks after (the generals had been killed in battle with the Persians).

questions.text: Which of these famous sailors commanded "The Golden Hind"?
questions.explanation:
Drake.

	Drake and Magellan sailed just about everywhere - although Magellan didn't survive his final voyage. The contributions of Columbus are well-known. Cabot was also an early explorer of North America.

questions.text: Henry Stanley went to Africa in search of the legendary David Livingstone. How did the trip end?
questions.correct: Stanley found Livingstone and returned home while Livingstone stayed in Africa
options: Stanley found Livingstone and both died on the way home
Stanley found Livingstone and both remained in Africa
questions.explanation:
Stanley found Livingstone and returned home while Livingstone stayed in Africa.

	"Dr. Livingstone, I presume" - according to legend. The colorful Stanley found Livingstone and returned to accolades. Livingstone remained behind and continued his work.

questions.text: Some trips are vertical, rather than horizontal. Which of these brave explorers perished during an attempt to climb Mt. Everest?
questions.explanation:
George Mallory.

	Mallory tried to conquer Everest in the 20's; his body was found several years ago by a subsequent expedition. Hillary succeeded in conquering the mountain. Shackleton and Peary were equally brave explorers - but they were polar explorers, not mountain climbers.

questions.text: The voyage of the Kon-Tiki is famous. Who made the trip?
questions.explanation:
Thor Heyerdahl.

	Heyerdahl was trying to prove a point about the ability of early sailors. Eric and Erickson were great sailors, but centuries earlier. Amundsen was a polar explorer.
